## Task 4 Calculate the **risk difference**, **relative risk**, and **odds ratio** for the association between diabetes and periodontitis. üí° In SPSS: **ANALYSIEREN** ‚Üí **DESKRIPTIVE STATISTIKEN** ‚Üí **KREUZTABELLEN** Then in the Crosstabs dialog, click **\[Cells...\]** and under **Percentages**, select **Row**, then click **Continue**.\ Next, click **\[Statistics...\]**, check **Risk**, and click **Continue**. **Calculate manually:** - **Risk difference (RD):**\ Subtract the percentage values $$ RD = p_{\text{diabetic with periodontitis}} - p_{\text{non-diabetic with periodontitis}} $$ - **Relative risk (RR):**\ Divide the percentage values instead of subtracting them.\ $$ RR = \frac{p_{\text{diabetic with periodontitis}}}{p_{\text{non-diabetic with periodontitis}}} $$ - **Odds ratio (OR):**\ Verify the value shown under *‚ÄúOdds ratio for ‚Ä¶‚Äù* by calculating: - The odds of periodontitis for diabetics:\ $$ \text{Odds}_{\text{diabetic}} = \frac{\text{number of diabetics with periodontitis}} {\text{number of diabetics without periodontitis}} $$ - Divided by the odds of periodontitis for non-diabetics:\ $$ \text{Odds}_{\text{non-diabetic}} = \frac{\text{number of non-diabetics with periodontitis}} {\text{number of non-diabetics without periodontitis}} $$ - Hence:\ $$ OR = \frac{\text{Odds}_{\text{diabetic}}}{\text{Odds}_{\text{non-diabetic}}} = \frac{a/b}{c/d} = \frac{a \times d}{b \times c} $$ where:\ - ( a ): diabetics **with** periodontitis\ - ( b ): diabetics **without** periodontitis\ - ( c ): non-diabetics **with** periodontitis\ - ( d ): non-diabetics **without** periodontitis
Let the 2√ó2 table be: | | Periodontitis (+) | Periodontitis (‚àí) | |--------------|-------------------|-------------------| | Diabetic | ( a ) | ( b ) | | Non-diabetic | ( c ) | ( d ) |
*diab √ó perio2 Crosstabulation* | diab | | perio2 = periodontitis | perio2 = no | **Total** | |--------------|--------------|-----------------|--------------|--------------| | **diabetes** | Count | 199 | 578 | **777** | | | \% within diab | 25.6% | 74.4% | 100.0% | | **no** | Count | 988 | 6,290 | **7,278** | | | \% within diab | 13.6% | 86.4% | 100.0% | | **Total** | Count | **1,187** | **6,868** | **8,055** | | | \% within diab | 14.7% | 85.3% | 100.0% | **Manual calculations** $$ RD = 25.6\% - 13.6\% = 12\% $$
{{< include ../utilities/badge-interpretation.html >}}
- ‚ö†Ô∏è Remember, this may only be an apparent association - The risk of periodontitis is 12 percentage points higher in the exposed group than in the unexposed group. - This means for every 100 people, about 12 more cases of periodontitis occur among those with diabetes.
$$ RR = \frac{25.6\%}{13.6\%} = 1.88 $$
{{< include ../utilities/badge-interpretation.html >}}
- Individuals with diabetes have 1.88 times the risk of periodontitis compared with those without diabetes.
$$ OR = \frac{25.6/74.4}{13.6/86.4} = \frac{25.6 \times 86.4}{74.4 \times 13.6} = \frac{2211.84}{1011.84} = 2.19 $$
{{< include ../utilities/badge-interpretation.html >}}
- People with diabetes have 2.19 times higher odds of having periodontitis compared with those without diabetes.
